entry.et: Middle English, from Old English pæth; akin to Old High German pfad path

def.dt: :a track specially constructed for a particular use
:a way of life, conduct, or thought
:the continuous series of positions or configurations that can be assumed in any motion or process of change by a moving or varying system
:a sequence of arcs in a network that can be traced continuously without retracing any arc

entry.et: New Latin, from Greek, from pathos, literally, suffering pathos

def.dt: :practitioner of a (specified) system of medicine that emphasizes one aspect of disease or its treatment naturopath
def.set: International Scientific Vocabulary, from Greek -pathēs, adjective, suffering, from pathos
def.dt: :one suffering from a disorder (of such a part or system) psychopath
:the area between the bases of a baseball field used by a base runner
:the path in the air or space made or followed by something (as a particle, an airplane, or a spacecraft) in flight
:the average distance traversed between collisions by particles (as molecules of a gas or free electrons in metal) in a system of agitated particles
:a path of ease or pleasure and especially sensual pleasure himself the primrose path of dalliance treads Shakespeare
